== Legal issues ==

sentences: Legal issues ==
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: Giggs was convicted for possession of a firearm in 2003, and sentenced to two years eight months in prison.
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: In February 2012, police searched a car Giggs was in and found an illegal firearm; Giggs spent six months remanded in custody, despite the driver admitting to owning the gun, as police accused Giggs of being aware of the firearm.
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: Giggs was acquitted on all charges.
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: Giggs often experienced venues cancelling events he was scheduled to appear at mere hours before the performance.
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: Giggs was dropped as support act for Lil Wayne before a 2006 tour without explanation.
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: These incidents have been linked to actions of the Metropolitan Police Service, who have been said to have specifically targeted Giggs.
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: Giggs believes that they "must have called the venues and threatened them with taking away their licences".
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: In 2010, he said that "every single thing I do that's supposed to be positive, they fuck up for me".
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: In 2013, he stated: "I don't want to get caught up in whose fault it is, or whether the police are after me [...]
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: I'm just happy to be making music again".
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: In 2009, the Metropolitan Police wrote to XL strongly advising the label not to sign Giggs, though they did anyway.
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: A 2010 tour planned by Giggs was cancelled due to police warnings.
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: In 2013, Giggs' London performance of material from When Will It Stop was cancelled by police, after they had given him the go-ahead.
section: == Legal issues ==

sentences: Giggs responded in a video publicly apologising to fans, reimbursing them for tickets, and sarcastically praising the police's attempts to "slow [him] down".
section: == Legal issues ==
